metadata.case_name: C. Gupta and Sudhansu Sekhar Mukherjee v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Detention orders under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, served on the appellants on the 26th February, 1950.

Grounds for detention served on the appellants on the 14th March, 1950. Specimen: assisting operations of Communist Party of India (CPI) declared unlawful under s.16 Indian Criminal Law Amendment Act 1908; fomented trouble amongst peasants of Howrah District as member of CPI Kishan front; incited tramways men and workers to violence in speeches at University Hall etc.
Under Bengal Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1930, a very large number of persons were detained; validity challenged in High Court, judgment expected end February 1950.
Preventive Detention Act, 1950 (Act IV of 1950) passed by Parliament in last week of February 1950.

Supplementary grounds served on 16th July 1950 in continuation of grounds of 14th March 1950. Specimen: As Secretary of Bengal Chatkar Mazdoor Union etc., carried disruptive programme of CPI; led procession at Howrah on 29th July 1948 preaching discontent.

Second set of grounds communicated on 22nd or 23rd July 1950 in continuation of 16th July order. Specimen: Threat in meeting 19th March 1947 under Calcutta Tramway Workers Union; presided over meeting 13th June 1948 advocating withdrawal of ban on CPI.
Appellants applied for Rule of habeas corpus separately under s.491 CrPC; High Court issued Rule on 21st July 1950 to Chief Secretary, Government of West Bengal.
High Court of Calcutta rejected the habeas corpus petitions in Criminal Miscellaneous Case No. 361 of 1950.
Appeal under Art. 132(1) Constitution of India to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether communication of grounds on 14th March 1950 complied with 'as soon as may be' under Art. 22(5) Constitution.
Whether there was non-compliance with procedure under Art. 22(5) and s.7 Preventive Detention Act in supplying grounds, depriving earliest opportunity for representation.
Whether supplementary grounds of 16th July 1950 were new/additional grounds not before detaining authority on 26th Feb 1950, violating Art. 22(5).
Whether grounds were vague, not enabling representation, equivalent to no grounds.
Whether large number of detention orders overnight indicated bad faith/lack of individual application of mind.

petitioner_arguments.text: Communication of grounds dated 14th March not 'as soon as may be' under Art. 22(5).
Non-compliance with Art. 22(5) and s.7 Preventive Detention Act in manner of supplying grounds, no earliest opportunity for representation.

Second communication of 16th July described as supplementary grounds in continuation, but actually additional/new grounds not before authority on 26th Feb; obligation absolute; shows not satisfied on original grounds, afterthought.
Grounds vague, could not be considered grounds at all; no representation possible; no satisfaction under s.3 Preventive Detention Act.
Large number of fresh detention orders overnight indicates bad faith, no individual application of mind.

respondent_arguments.text: Delay in grounds justified by large number of cases post Preventive Detention Act.
Supplementary grounds not new but details of original grounds of 14th March.
Grounds not vague; procedural requirements complied with.

court_reasoning.text: Agree with High Court: delay from 26 Feb to 14 Mar justified as Provincial Govt dealt with large number suddenly after Preventive Detention Act passed; no failure under Art. 22(5).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Having regard to the fact that the Provincial Government had thus suddenly to deal with a large number of cases on one day, unable to accept contention.

court_reasoning.text: Applying principles from Case No. 22 of 1950: no non-compliance depriving representation opportunity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: We have discussed in detail the nature of the two rights conferred under article 22(5).

court_reasoning.text: Supplementary grounds not new/additional but details of second heads in original 14th March grounds; look at contents not just description; not afterthought; communicated as soon as may be per Case No. 22 principles.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Examining the contents... we find that they only furnish details... unable to treat them as new grounds.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds not vague per Case No. 22; vague grounds not same as irrelevant; court examines sufficiency for representation, not for govt satisfaction under s.3.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court considered each appellant's grounds not vague; procedural requirement not infringed.

court_reasoning.text: Per Das J: Large number overnight not bad faith; minds already applied under local Acts, fresh orders under new Act not requiring elaborate re-application.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The minds of the authorities having already been made up... an elaborate application of mind... does not appear to me to be necessary.

holdings.text: Communication of grounds on 14th March complied with Art. 22(5) 'as soon as may be'.
No non-compliance with Art. 22(5)/s.7 Preventive Detention Act; opportunity for representation provided.
Supplementary grounds not new but elaborative details of original; valid.
Grounds not vague; sufficient for representation and govt satisfaction.
No bad faith in bulk detention orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: Case No. 22 of 1950 (The State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya)
precedents_cited.relevance: Discussed nature of rights under Art. 22(5); principles on 'as soon as may be', vagueness of grounds applied here.
Explanation of what constitutes new grounds.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for appeal; requires grounds communicated as soon as may be, opportunity for representation.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
sections: sub-clause (ii) of clause (a) of sub-section (1) of section 3
statutes_cited.relevance: Detention orders made under; satisfaction of authority; communication of grounds.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal against the Calcutta High Court's rejection of habeas corpus petitions, upholding the detentions under Preventive Detention Act 1950 and finding full compliance with Art. 22(5) Constitution.

key_quotes.text: "Having regard to the fact that the Provincial Government had thus suddenly to deal with a large number of cases on one day, we are unable to accept this contention of the appellants."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A description of the contents of the second communication as supplementary grounds does not necessarily make them additional or new grounds. One has to look at the contents."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satisfaction of the Provincial Government, is not a matter for examination by the court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits judicial review to procedural aspects.
